Award.AwardTitle: Atlanta Lecture Series in Combinatorics and Graph Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Since 2010, Emory University, the Georgia Institute of Technology, and Georgia State University have hosted 15 mini-conferences of the Atlanta Lecture Series in Graph Theory and Combinatorics. This award provides support to continue this series for the academic year 2015/2016, with two more conferences in Fall 2015 and Spring 2016. These will be held at Georgia Institute of Technology and Georgia State University, respectively. Each conference will feature two one-hour lectures by one distinguished researcher, four one-hour lectures by established researchers mainly from the southeast region, and four 30-minute talks by junior researchers and graduate students. The website is at http://www.math.gsu.edu/~gchen/ALS17/ALS17.html.

Combinatorics and graph theory have undergone dramatic development in the past few decades. For the previous 15 meetings, the featured speakers were leading experts in the following areas of combinaroics and graph theory: structural graph theory, extremal graph theory, random graphs and graph percolations, hypergraphs and set theory, and the Szemeredi regularity lemma. The speaker pool not only has a good gender balance but also consists of a nice blend of senior, well-known researchers and young rising stars. The series has become a major event for the combinatorics community in the southeast region and beyond, providing opportunities to strengthen collaborations among researchers and institutions within the southeast region of the United States. These two mini-conferences will be a continuation of the series.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the academic year 2015-2016,  we successfully organized two mini-conferences of the Atlanta Lecture Series in Combinatorics and Graph Theory:

The 16th Mini-conference at Georgia Institute of Technology, November 14 - 15, 2015

The  17th Mini-conference at Georgia State University, April 30 - May 1, 2016

 

ALS 16: The conference featured two 1-hour talks by  Noga Alon, a Baumritter Professor of Mathematics and Computer Science in Tel Aviv University, Israel. Also featured were  four 1 hour talks given by  four well-known graph theorists:  Abdrzej Ruchiski,    Adam Michiewicz University/Emory University Tao Jiang, Miami University,  Santosh Vempala}, Georgia Institute of Technology,  Lutz Warnke},  University of Cambridge

These talks were supplemented by two 25 minute talks by young faculty: Chun-Hung Liu, Princeton University  and f Songling Shan, Vanderbilt University 


 ALS -17:
The conference featured  two 1-hour talks by Alexandr V. Kostochka, The  University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. 
Also featured were  four 1 hour talks by :well-known graph theorists:  Mark Ellingham,   Vanderbilt University,  Michael Jacobson,  University of Colorado Denver, Michael Plummer,  Vanderbilt University, Andre Raspaud,  Bordeaux University. 


These talks were supplemented by four  25 minute talks by young faculty and graduate students: Anton Bernshteyn, The University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign,Victor Falgas-Ravry, Vanderbilt University, Jill Faudree,  University of Alaska, Yan Wang,  Georgia Institute of Technology   


Thus, as proposed, both  mini-conferences featured one of the top combinatorialists in the country and four other major researchers,as well as provided an opportunity for some younger faculty and graduate students to present their work.
